case_vignette: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several skin-colored, nontender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple painless bumps on my stomach and arms that don't itch.
Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or difficulty breathing?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms.
Have you had any recent injuries or infections?
My brother had chickenpox one month ago.
Have you been in close contact with anyone who has had chickenpox recently?
No, just my brother who had it a month ago.
Have you had any other illnesses or medical conditions in the past?
I've been previously healthy.
Have you had any allergies or reactions to medications in the past?
No, I haven't had any allergies or reactions to medications.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my diet or lifestyle.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
The only different thing is that I go to daycare three times a week.
Have you noticed any changes in your behavior or mood?
No, there haven't been any changes in my behavior or mood.
Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or eating habits?
No, my eating habits and appetite haven't changed.
Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or sleep quality?
No, my sleep has been normal.
Have you noticed any changes in your energy levels or activity level?
No, my energy and activity levels have been normal.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin or nails?
Just the bumps on my stomach and arms, nothing else.
Have you noticed any changes in your hair or scalp?
No, there haven't been any changes in my hair or scalp.
Have you noticed any changes in your eyes or vision?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient reports having multiple painless bumps on the stomach and arms that do not itch. There are no other accompanying symptoms. The patient's brother had chickenpox one month ago. The patient has previously been healthy with no history of allergies or reactions to medications. There have been no recent changes in diet or lifestyle, but the patient does attend daycare three times a week. There are no changes in behavior, mood, eating habits, appetite, sleep, energy, activity levels, hair, or scalp.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Molluscum contagiosum.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, commonly known as shingles.
